column1: Table 1 and 2 from paper combined - alphabetical order by dataset or data repository name

column6: Note

column1: Abdominal and Direct Fetal ECG Database (ADFECGDB)

column6: Longitudinal imaging and behavioural data including mental health metrics, with sex-disaggregated analyses

column3: Health data, genomic, measurements and wearables
column6: American population only.

The BioImage Archive is a free, publicly available online resource which stores and distributes biological images. It accepts submissions of data from any imaging modality, as long as the data are either associated with a peer-reviewed publication, or of value beyond a single experiment.

column3: Omics, health data, clinical data, dental data
column6: Bradford based biobank following 60,000 individuals. Providing multiomic data, health data, clinical data, dental data and others. Inlcudes trios and pregnancy data.
UK-based biobank for breast tissue, breast cells and blood samples from breast cancer patients
Atlas of various cardiac MRI projects.
Over 512,000 adult participants. Questionnaires, physical measurements, blood and biological samples

column3: Omics (genomics and proteomics) and clinical data
column6: include RNA-Seq Gene Expression Quantification data of several cancer types

column2: General health, mental health and other diseases
column6: Provides access to anonymised mental health records from the UK’s NHS Trusts
Breastfeeding, Pregnancy and birth

Database of genotype-phenotype. Needs quite a lot of paperwork to get access. This database holds data from various studies. Eg. Women's health initiative (mentioned above) and California Teachers Study (CTS): Whole Genome Sequences From Under-Represented Populations
It's like the EU equivalent of dbGaP. Seems easier to get access. eg. Breast Cancer in very young women https://ega-archive.org/studies/EGAS00001001908
Biobank of Estonia. Mostly genomic array with some WGS and other omics. (There is an application cost on top of compute cost.)
synthetic data generated from the FECGSYN simulator
retrospective dataset of 16,651 pregnancies monitored at St. Mary’s Hospital, London
Genomics, epigenomics, metabolomics and proteomics of Scottish population (~20K individuals).
Focused on British-Pakistani and -Bangladeshi communities.

Various datasets: 100K Genomes, NHS Genomic Medicine Services. Both for rare disease and cancer research. Working on new datasets such as multimodal for cancer. The current omic data is not available to all, only for pilot studies.

curated gene expression DataSets, as well as original Series and Platform records in the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository. (Eg. Intergrative Multi-Omics of Asian Pregnant Mother https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE182409)

column3: Omics (transcriptomics), histology (genomics + phenotypes with restricted access).
column6: Heavily used resource for normal tissue gene expression - 233 of 714 tissues from women.

column6: This data repository includes lots of diseases (e.g., breast, ovarian and acute presentation of pregnant women)

column1: Maternal Health and High-Risk Pregnancy Dataset
column6: include mother’s age, gravida (number of pregnancies), weight, height, blood pressure, gestational age, and fetal health status.
410 mothers, aim to exploratory obtain maternal mental health symptom profiles
Repository for medical images related to COVID-19 and clinical data for development of medical image based AI for use in detection, diagnosis, prognosis and monitoring of COVID-19.

column3: Clinical (Patient demographics, clinical notes; procedure and diagnosis data (i.e ICD-9 coded data); patient outcome data (length of stay, etc.)), imaging reports; physiological (i.e. vital signs, lab reports); medication (i.e. prescriptions and administration details);
column6: De-identified health data for patients admitted to critical care at large tertiary care hospitals.

Updated MIMIC-III includes increased data from previously 40,000 admissions to 523,740 admissions, electronic medication records, improved data structure including module (hospital, ICU, note, etc.), wider range of healthcare applications and research.

column1: MRC CBU Openly Available Datasets resource
Multi-Modality Ovarian Tumor Ultrasound (MMOTU) image dataset
column6:
1469 2d ultrasound images and 170 contrast enhanced ultrasonography (CEUS) images with pixel-wise and global-wise annotations. Specifically designed for Unsupervised Cross-Domain Semantic Segmentation. See article: 
 https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2207.06799

column3: Imaging (MRI, CT, X-ray) and clinical (GP records and patient information)
column6: National data sets collect information from care records, systems and organisations. This is used to inform policy and monitor, and improve care. This data repository includes many diseases ( based on diagnosis code) and some specific topic to women (e.g., Female Genital Mutilation datasets)

column3: Clinical, omics and neuro-signal recordings (EEG and EGG)
column6: A centralised repository for US-funded mental health studies, including adolescent and adult datasets
Mammography imaging database (~750k)
data repository includes several datasets to predict pregnancy outcomes (e.g., complications) using machine learning and deep learning techniques

column3: Genotype, linked clinical records, health data
column6: UK based biobank with a wider range of participant age than UK biobank, and more focus on diverse ethnic backgrounds.
about physiological signals. This data repository includes several smaller datasets, which has up to 150-160 female records (~50% total records)

column1: Postnatal maternal depression dataset in South African community cohort
column6: Small dataset with around 80 participant, South African cohort, the study investigated associations between adverse maternal experiences with postnatal maternal depression and child social-emotional outcomes

column1: PREdiction of Clinical Outcomes from Genomic profiles
column6: Genomic profiles and clinical outcomes of many disease including breast and ovarian cancer (data deposited in GEO, mentioned below)

captures menopause-related consultations and prescriptions, enabling large-scale observational studies of menopausal symptom management and associated risks

Examines provision of critical care after surgery, epidemiology of perioperative risk, outcomes and critical care after inpatient surgery in the UK.

column1: Abbreviation List: CT: Computed Tomography, ECG: Electrocardiogram, EEG: Electroencephalogram, fMRI: Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging, GP: General Practitioner, H&E: Hematoxylin and Eosin, ICD-9: International Classification of Diseases, 9th Revision, MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging, PET: Positron Emission Tomography.
